1.text: I speak the truth in Christ; I am not lying, as confirmed by my conscience in the Holy Spirit.

2.text: I have deep sorrow and unceasing anguish in my heart.

3.text: For I could wish that I myself were cursed and cut off from Christ for the sake of my brothers, my own flesh and blood,

4.text: the people of Israel. Theirs is the adoption as sons; theirs the divine glory and the covenants; theirs the giving of the law, the temple worship, and the promises.

5.text: Theirs are the patriarchs, and from them proceeds the human descent of Christ, who is God over all, forever worthy of praise! Amen.

6.text: It is not as though God’s word has failed. For not all who are descended from Israel are Israel.

7.text: Nor because they are Abraham’s descendants are they all his children. On the contrary, “Through Isaac your offspring will be reckoned.”

8.text: So it is not the children of the flesh who are God’s children, but it is the children of the promise who are regarded as offspring.

9.text: For this is what the promise stated: “At the appointed time I will return, and Sarah will have a son.”

10.text: Not only that, but Rebecca’s children were conceived by one man, our father Isaac.

11.text: Yet before the twins were born or had done anything good or bad, in order that God’s plan of election might stand,

12.text: not by works but by Him who calls, she was told, “The older will serve the younger.”

13.text: So it is written: “Jacob I loved, but Esau I hated.”

14.text: What then shall we say? Is God unjust? Certainly not!

15.text: For He says to Moses: “I will have mercy on whom I have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I have compassion.”

16.text: So then, it does not depend on man’s desire or effort, but on God’s mercy.

17.text: For the Scripture says to Pharaoh: “I raised you up for this very purpose, that I might display My power in you, and that My name might be proclaimed in all the earth.”

18.text: Therefore God has mercy on whom He wants to have mercy, and He hardens whom He wants to harden.

19.text: One of you will say to me, “Then why does God still find fault? For who can resist His will?”

20.text: But who are you, O man, to talk back to God? Shall what is formed say to Him who formed it, “Why did You make me like this?”

21.text: Does not the potter have the right to make from the same lump of clay one vessel for special occasions and another for common use?

22.text: What if God, intending to show His wrath and make His power known, bore with great patience the vessels of His wrath, prepared for destruction?

23.text: What if He did this to make the riches of His glory known to the vessels of His mercy, whom He prepared in advance for glory—

24.text: including us, whom He has called not only from the Jews, but also from the Gentiles?

25.text: As He says in Hosea: “I will call them ‘My People’ who are not My people, and I will call her ‘My Beloved’ who is not My beloved,”

26.text: and, “It will happen that in the very place where it was said to them, ‘You are not My people,’ they will be called ‘sons of the living God.’”

27.text: Isaiah cries out concerning Israel: “Though the number of the Israelites is like the sand of the sea, only the remnant will be saved.

28.text: For the Lord will carry out His sentence on the earth thoroughly and decisively.”

29.text: It is just as Isaiah foretold: “Unless the Lord of Hosts had left us descendants, we would have become like Sodom, we would have resembled Gomorrah.”

30.text: What then will we say? That the Gentiles, who did not pursue righteousness, have obtained it, a righteousness that is by faith;

31.text: but Israel, who pursued a law of righteousness, has not attained it.

32.text: Why not? Because their pursuit was not by faith, but as if it were by works. They stumbled over the stumbling stone,

33.text: as it is written: “See, I lay in Zion a stone of stumbling and a rock of offense; and the one who believes in Him will never be put to shame.”
